citations.narrative:
Medical records were not complete for eleven dogs at the facility. Upon record review, the medical records provided
descriptions of the concerns observed by the facility, but did not have an outlined treatment plan. Additionally, two of the
records did not state the identity of the animal for the observations recorded. Further review of the records identified two
more records where eye care treatments were written, but the dates of administration were not recorded.
Complete records identify medical problems as they arise, ensure adequate care is provided, and enables close
monitoring of conditions as they progress. Facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make them
available during inspection. If a problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or illness) the date and a description of the
problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedure performed must be
included in these medical records. Each record must include the identity of the animal, as well as the names of all
treatments administered and the dates of administration.

Various areas along the perimeter fence no longer stand at six feet tall. Upon today’s inspection, the fence line
immediately to the left of the gate now measures 69 inches tall. The fence line along the south side of the facility
measured 69 – 70 inches tall.
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside
the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their
enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been
issued in writing by the Administrator.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B" license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 7th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.13(b) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Medical records were not complete for eleven dogs at the facility. Upon record review, the medical records provided 
descriptions of the concerns observed by the facility, but did not have an outlined treatment plan. Additionally, two of the 
records did not state the identity of the animal for the observations recorded. Further review of the records identified two 
more records where eye care treatments were written, but the dates of administration were not recorded. 
Complete records identify medical problems as they arise, ensure adequate care is provided, and enables close 
monitoring of conditions as they progress. Facilities must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make them 
available during inspection. If a problem is identified (such as a disease, injury, or illness) the date and a description of the 
problem, examination findings, test results, plan for treatment and care, and treatment procedure performed must be 
included in these medical records. Each record must include the identity of the animal, as well as the names of all 
treatments administered and the dates of administration. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Various areas along the perimeter fence no longer stand at six feet tall. Upon today’s inspection, the fence line 
immediately to the left of the gate now measures 69 inches tall. The fence line along the south side of the facility 
measured 69 – 70 inches tall. 
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from 
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility. The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of 
the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside 
the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their 
enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been 
issued in writing by the Administrator. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “B" license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant.

All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 7th, 2023 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
